commentBody: Incredible construction and a fun puzzle to boot!!

Interesting.  Thought this might be one of those ones that was more fun for the constructor than the puzzler, but this is pretty remarkable to look over at the end. I can only imagine the limitations this places on your word list when building...
That ANI clue had me buffaloed for a while. (But I don't think blackbirds ride on buffaloes.)

Our inexplicably self-appointed alphadoppelganger, Lewis, will sadly find that the number of double letters in this puzzle is exactly...

Zero.

Took me back to when I had regular struggles with tuesdays. 

Thanks for keeping me humble!!
Wow, insane construction! Very impressive

Okay I liked it! A fun exercise for a day of awesome joy. 

(Joy things: I got invited to beta the new Procreate, which probably means they're close to release because I'm nobody but it's still fun; I did a Trader Joe's run and got yummy things; and now a metaphorically yummy puzzle, whee! Also I couldn't resist doing a sentence in CV-alternating format to match the puzzle.)

Nice job.
Stunning to look back at the grid on completion. The "wowed" in the center sums up exactly how I feel about this clever construction. Well done.
That must have been nigh on impossible to construct. Felt tough for a Tuesday, too. 8:30, usually I'm under 6 on Tuesdays

Wow quite a feat of construction! Really liked the fact that there wasn't much crosswordese despite the constraints of the theme and that the difficulty level seemed just a tad higher than most Tuesdays. Nicely done.
Take note, everyone, that in order to avoid the issue of "and sometimes Y," Marshall left Y out of the puzzle altogether.
Kudos to Marshal!
I liked it a lot!
That’s a very impressive puzzle and fun to solve!
Utterly impressive how one can construct a crossword under this constraint, while making it accessible enough for a Tuesday and not having overly difficult fill.

The ratio of time spent by the constructor making the puzzle vs. time spent by us solving it, this one might be way off the chart.
Hats off to the constructor for an overimaginative puzzle.
I am very impressed with Mr. Herrmann‘s construction, especially given the need of an easier fill for a Tuesday. Knowing the theme stopped me several times from making errors. Thanks!

Wow, a memorable, rad, and epic one! Very solid! 

(That's as long of a review as I could muster with the same vowel/consonant pattern! I was upset "impressive" wouldn't work!!!)

I, Bob, like the theme!  

I find your debut puzzle's theme even more impressive!
BRILLIANT! Excellent Tuesday puzzle. Or should I say it was…dIvInE!
One of the most fun puzzles I've done. Once I got the theme clue in the middle it was just pure joy building and building as I kept solving and seeing the theme play out.

WOWED, I’m just WOWED by this theme and its execution.  Even the idea of imposing a formal restraint on every single square in the grid is daunting.  To implement that theme across four spanners, with a bare minimum of crosswordese, is truly impressive.  But to finish off the meal with a few choice mignardises like crossing [bonds tightly] with [local bond] and two members of [Santa’s team] —that’s real class.  Take a MIC drop Mr. Herrmann!

I didn't notice the pattern while solving, but glad the constructor was able to pull it off. Right now I'm in tears after heading straight to YouTube upon finishing the puzzle to listen to my favorite song of Oleta Adams from the 1990. (It's not "Get Here," which is also gorgeous.) I had the privilege of seeing her perform it live at the Paramount Theater in Oakland in the early 90s. This video isn't from that concert (she didn't have a symphony orchestra in Oakland), but it might be even more powerful: https://youtu.be/xwUHhADURTI?si=u33kI8TxC4GzHqRN
Great puzzle!
Wow!  Amazing crossword with such a tight and well-executed theme!
Clever construction and a very fun solve!

WOW!!
What a great Tuesday. The revealer was easy to get and instantly made the puzzle so much easier, but at the same time, once I got the revealer, I marvelled at the puzzle for the rest of the solve. What a feat of construction! And such great spanners for a Tuesday! The constructor deserves many kudos, especially for MEDICINE CABINET.
Brilliant!!! Absolutely brilliant!
Realizing the truth of 35A left me 27D.
4 spanners with that theme is very impressive, this will be a top contender for crossword of the year. No overly tricky clues, obscure tricia or excessive crosswordese. Just a fun puzzle
Amazing puzzle, Marshal!  Clever clues and fun to solve, but thinking about what went into the construction to pull this off, I’m WOWED!
Pretty amazing feat—and very fun to solve. Nicely done!

Wowed by the theme when I got the revealer, but my enthusiasm waned as I kept clanging into cultural references that were out of my wheelhouse. MOC, ONO, HILITER, VICECOP, HORA AND OLETA all crossing with the two 15 long phrases made for a very rough time.

What a disappointment that the constructor’s note did not follow the alternate vowels rule.

Just kidding of course!!!

Also, he got “iterated” in there.

I notice that (at the time I'm writing this) both commenters who tried to make a comment with alternating vowels and consonants made a mistake and broke the pattern. Makes one appreciate more the difficult task the constructor set himself. And he had to worry about all the crosses. And he managed to do it all without a lot of arcane fill.

🤯🤯🤯 what?!

A choppy solve for sure but in the end I can't fault that genius construction.

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/09/08/tuesday-september-9-2025/#ny Thanks, Mr. Herrmann, for the explanation of your theme's genesis. I too have read Jeff Chen's commentary about the usefulness of words with alternating consonants and vowels; it's interesting to see it taken as you did.

A Tuesday puzzle that was elegantly constructed and fun to solve—they don't get any better than that.  The puzzle Marshal Hermann had to solve himself to find words and phrases that would meet the criterion he chose to place on the fills is impressive all by itself.  

I'm going to do a celebratory dance in honor of your dazzling achievement, Marshal, but I can't decide on a HULA or a HORA.

I LOVED this puzzle! Understanding the alternation of vowels and consonants led to me solving this much more quickly than I usually do on a Tuesday.

By the way, I have a slight confusion: the constructor refers to “téte-a-téte” has alternating vowels and consonants, which, of course it does not. What am I not understanding here?
Maybe the best puzzle I've seen all year. Really impressive construction, right level of difficulty for a Tuesday, great revealer and FOUR fifteen letter entires? And no Ys?

"Ha! I beat you at 'Wheel of Fortune'!"
"I'd like to buy a scowl."

(You spin some, you lose some.)
Breathtaking!
On the easier side (it’s Tuesday) but the construction is impressive! 👏👏

Hmm! Just recently was able to digitize the only copy I have of an episode of Wheel of Fortune from 1997, that hundreds of students had not found on YouTube. My appearance on Wheel of Fortune. Unfortunately I didn’t catch on until reading the column about the alternating consonants and vowels. Which I might argue would possibly make solving a wheel puzzle harder
LOVED IT. I’m in awe.
Everyone is so smart here. This was one of the tougher Tuesdays for me.
Hats off to the constructor for an impressive crossword, and hats off to me for my 500-day streak!
Simply amazing.  I mean, wow.  A bit harder than a normal Tuesday (my solve time was twice my Tuesday average), but it got easier once I got the revealer.
Definitely a bit more challenging than most Tuesdays but well worth it for the pleasure of solving! This one was a real treat
This was phenomenal construction and a joy to solve. Thank you, Marshal, for this beauty. Truly Chef’s Kiss worthy.
I VOWEL always remember this Xword puzzle.
AwEsOmE

I'm rarely impressed by a puzzle's construction but this one wowed even me. Knowing every other letter in the grid would be a vowel actually helped me to fill it, too - which was welcome, as I found the fill quite hard for a Tuesday (as usual in my case, due to the inclusion of quite a few names and brands unknown to me. I desperately wanted OLETA to be OLEnA). I still completed the puzzle in my average time for this time in the week - hats off to the constructor for managing to show off their skill with no detriment to the solving experience: the two often do not go hand in hand.
Outstanding construction. And a pleasurable solve.
This puzzle could have easily been a Wednesday, and that’s a compliment to the constructor.

Two things that shouldn't be possible:

1. When the soloist with the symphony (usually piano or violin) plays a four-movement piece from memory (no sheet music!)

2. Construction of a puzzle like this

take that, AI!
I’m not inconsonant, just having regular vowel movements
This puzzle is an AMAZING ACCOMPLISHMENT!

I rarely comment, but had to join the chorus of wows.  What a great puzzle!
Also, does it say something about me that my first thought when reading the clue for 1D was proctologist?

Nice to see my hometown referenced *twice*! (Would have been *thrice*, but the Big Three has stopped making SEDANS altogether. Note on sedans--most people think the distinction between a sedan and a coupe is the number of doors--four vs. two. It is not: the true distinction is in cabin size--33 CUBIC feet or more, it's a sedan, less than 33, it's a coupe. (The clue writers presumably knew this. Bully for them!) Here's some pretty pictures of two-door sedans: https://tiny.cc/jzas001 (Anyone else remember *Bored of the Rings*?)

Joining the well deserved chorus of wows. I thought I found it a little trickier than the average Tuesday as I’m currently battling a bout of ill health, so it was encouraging to read the general tone was one of ‘tougher than average’. I must be getting better (pauses to cough up a lung).
Well, that was just amazing.  Technically brilliant and fun.

35 Across should have been clued as Purchase on “Wheel of Fortune” … or every other letter of this puzzle’s CLUES, not “grid”, seeing as 18 Across ends in a vowel and 19 Across begins with a vowel. There are several other similar instances scattered throughout the puzzle. Otherwise a very enjoyable puzzle to solve!
Thank you, Marshal. A joy.

I did not pick up on the unusual aspect until after I finished the puzzle, simply because I didn't read the whole clue at 35A.  LOL  That'll teach me!

I am up super early today.  Both today and yesterday are unusually pleasant--actually chilly this early!  Wish I could have enjoyed the weather respite by hiking at a park .  

Nice puzzle.  I put in ALMAY at 2D...instant error!  I'm not up on brands...hypoallergenic make-up a necessity (when I used to bother to wear any, that is.)  

Does the NYT really think they will suddenly inspire us to fork over more shekels and then nag our unwilling loved ones to work the puzzles?  I'm lucky that PhysDau will play along when she's here for a visit...but I notice that if she doesn't finish a puzzle (such as a big Sunday offering) she declines to take it with her.  Maybe in 20 years, if she retires.

This puzzle supersizes my high regard for constructors. I’m delighted to see so much positive feedback for Marshal Herrmann’s extraordinary work. It is IMHO the most memorable Tuesday since I began solving in 2020.

Impressive feat of construction, and I will add to the chorus of wows here. I realized the theme only on solving the revealer, and am impressed by the four 15 letter spanners. Nice puzzle, and I enjoyed solving it.
Amazing.

Kind of disappointing for the OREOphiles among us, eh?

Seriously, this was fun and an amazing feat of construction.

Thank you!

I guess I'm the only one who had this experience:

When I got to 35A, I only half read the clue and promptly filled in VOWEL and didn't realize this was the revealer clue.

I finished the puzzle and decided there was no revealer and spent quite a bit of time looking at 14A, 17A, 52A and 56A trying to figure out what the phrases had in common. Came up with nothing.

Then I decided the NYT ran a themeless puzzle on a Tuesday.

Finally, I looked one more time at the clues and noticed the rest of the clue for 35A and saw how exceptional this puzzle was.

I can't really think of an excuse.
This seems too difficult for a Tuesday puzzle.
I love spanners, and of course these were especially challenging but fun.  They were certainly challenging to the constructor I’m sure, so many thanks Marshal.
Just brilliant 🤩
Wow. well done

When I got the revealer I was like “No way - that can’t be.” Then I went back and looked at the fills I had. Even MEDICINE CABINET. 🤯

Nicely done! 👏

As your resident alphadoppeltotter, a role I’ve inexplicably taken in the past eight years, it is my duty to inform you that the puzzle has an unusually low number of double letters, at zero, where unusual is any number less than five.  Since I’ve begun my service to you, this has never happened before.

Alas, this feat comes with an asterisk, as it is theme related, and cannot count as a record.  May I add that my labor was exceedingly and refreshingly light, a well-earned vacation, if I may so boldly say. 

I remain your humble servant, ever on the alert.
We have an ONO but no EMU.  Can it really be said that this is the alternating-consonant-vowel-crossword to end all alternating-consonant-vowel-crosswords without an EMU?
Hero!
Marshal used the phrase “striking and irresistible” in his commentary.  The phrase perfectly describes his crossword, too.  Bravo!

(In keeping with the theme):

I liked it a lot.
Holy smokes, what an achievement!  This is an impressive piece of construction:  bravo!!
Best Tuesday ever.  Amazed!

Marshal’s first Times puzzle (Tuesday, 1/16/24) had a knock-me-over-with-a-feather theme, and if you haven’t done it, I suggest you put your life on hold and do it now.

In just two puzzles, he has established himself as a masterful grid manipulator.  I have no idea what he will come up with next, but you can be sure when I see his name atop the empty grid, I will cocoon myself, put a “do not disturb” sign on my door, and jump right into it.

What struck me and stays with me is that Marshal tooled around with this puzzle for more than a year before submitting it.  I find that persistence and drive for excellence powerfully inspiring.  Bravo sir!  

Wowed and inspired and eager for more.  Now that is one lovely place from which to springboard into the day.  Thank you for this, Marshal!
Challenging but fun. More of these please
Incredible, without a doubt. The spanners, the theme, the clues, the symmetry. Perfect. No notes.

WOWOWOWAPOWORAPOY


". . .and sometimes Y. . ."

Cute Tuesday puzzle. Think the constructor was wise to eschew "Y", given its dual nature.

Found OVERIMAGINATIVE a bit jarring, with "over" rather than "overly". And MORETOCOMELATER seemed a bit contrived. But, given the constraint imposed by the theme, the fill seemed pretty lively. Enjoyed solving this one.
Outstanding!
Pure genius. What a ride!

Well, it was fine. Though upon finishing, it would have been nice to see the alternating squares in the grid flash on and off to highlight the chessboard-like nature of the pattern.

As for clever or difficult construction, I don’t see it at all. From his notes, he clearly started by running his word list through a simple program that left only entries with alternating vowels and consonants - he even tells us the percentage of words remaining. Then, he finds the few 15 letter entries that he can use as spanners and it’s off to the races. In fact, using only entries from his remaining word list, ANY complete construction would NECESSARILY retain this pattern.

Would it be difficult for a human to complete such a grid unaided?  VERY difficult. But with modern construction tools, and the fact that one of the things computers are vastly superior to humans at is stepping through multiple possibilities very fast, not too difficult.  I am uniquely unimpressed that he was able to produce such a grid in the modern era. Sorry.
Surprised to see such positive comments, this just felt like a boring and easy Friday to me

Enjoyable solve and a really impressive feat of construction. Two thumbs up. I hope I didn't overlook something but I'm a bit surprised that apparently no one has mentioned the previous appearance of this theme - a Tuesday from April 17, 2018 by Wren Schultz. But today's is particularly impressive with those double stacks of grid-spanners top and bottom. And... couldn't help but wonder about a possible weird clue or answer for VOWEL - "ACONSONANTCOMPANION." And...here's the link to that Tuesday puzzle by Wren Schultz. In that one the clue was: "Every other letter in this puzzle's grid(!)" That's pretty impressive. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/17/2018&g=65&d=A I'll shut up now. ....
Oh. My. Goodness! What an amazing feat this puzzle is! It was so much fun. And perfect for Tuesday. Kudos, Marshal! Well done!

It took me a bit to find a toehold and I ended up solving this chaotically, bouncing around the grid, until it started to fill, and then I ended up at just about 40 percent under my average time. Put me in the camp as one who enjoyed it…and was impressed by the constructing feat, which I went back to admire once I finished. Since I’ve solved every day since 1/1/2018, the start of my retirement, I would have solved the other puzzle he mentions in his note, but I’m going back to check it out now.

A fun little bonus (that is a necessary result of today's theme):

If you look at every diagonal (in either direction), they are made up of only vowels or only consonants.

That's rather amazing! I did not notice the trick until the revealer at 35A, but it did make the rest of the puzzle solve faster.

MEDICINE CABINET. I've not seen one in any home built since 1980.

2D/18A is probably in Natick Territory for many. 
Did IDA use AVEDA?


MORE TO COME LATER, please, Marshal?
COLOR me WOWED !!! Cannot say enough how much I love this. Gorgeous grid with multiple grid-spanning entries on a Tuesday with the vowel restriction !!!!! Lovely work.
Insane puzel! Clearly, I am inept at this but you…wow!

Lovely Tuesday, especially once I sorted COMET and CUPID, and ruled out Vixen!
(I got a PB, but it doesn't count. Two days in a row I have had to cut away from the puzzle part way through. Instead of saving, I have been granted a complete reset. No bueno.)
I always admire the puzzle creators,  but even more so when one alternates such as today.  Bravo!

Tuesday or Friday??? I had a hard time with this one, and had to cheat by looking up a number of clues. However, my compliments to Marshal Herrmann. Vowels every other square, across as well as down, is truly brilliant.
Among other things, I want to give a little love to the double stack of two spanning phrases often said back to back: "MORE TO COME LATER" and "ON A SEPARATE NOTE"

We had a hero today.

Spanners in a Tuesday puzzle? A BIT OF AWESOME, NO?

Speaking of Nathaniel Hawthorne, the clue for TALE, [Bit of writing of Nathaniel Hawthorne], seems a bit awkward to me. Am I missing some wordplay here?

Speaking of Nathaniel Hawthorne, I was playing nude miniature golf with him once when Taylor Swift and Genghis Khan rode up juggling chainsaws(kinda scary when you're playing nude miniature golf) and said in unison "There's no such thing as 'too fanciful'" and then rode their gators off into the sunset, still juggling, still snuggling.

Speaking of Nathaniel Hawthorne, I like his quote: "No man can, for any considerable time, wear one face to himself, and another to the multitude, without finally getting bewildered as to which is the true one."

Speaking of Nathaniel Hawthorne, what about a crossword where every other letter is scarlet?!?!

I really liked the alternating vowel/consonant theme in this puzzle.  But it did seem to lead to a *lot* of proper name clues in very specialized areas.  I had a lot of time on the last few squares and ended up having to brute force a few.

Fabulous!

Did I mention that I loved this puzzle?

@Sam, really surprised that you have never heard of the Plastic ONO Band; it has been in the puzzle often enough! In fact, this is where I learned about it. I'm sure someone else will come up with the stats. 

The revealer was all I needed...sent me zooming through my answers, and made it easy to correct my thinking on wrong ones before they hit the puzzle. "Nope, two adjacent vowels." 

Faves: Loved having a different clue for OLE. So tired of things like "stadium cry." 
[Crack expert?] cracked me up! I was envisioning the stereotypical view of the plumber under the sink...'nuff said. Loved that I was wrong on that one! (Some COMIC may make use of that vision.)
AVEDA: Nice to have another company named instead of Estee or Almay. Fun fact: Aveda makes the most delicious herbal tea. Hot or iced, and the longer it steeps, the better it is. 

Major, major kudos to Marshal Hermann for this construction. I can't imagine how much work went into figuring out the grid with an "every other" constraint. Congratulations on this excellent puzzle, and more like this would be most welcome!

As impressive as it is to have all the words with alternating consonants and vowels, it's even more impressive that the pattern holds true across all the blank spaces as well! In both directions, even when there is more than one blank adjacent.
Great theme. Super clever and, I can imagine, very hard to create. Well done.
Very clever and fun puzzle. Thanks
If not for 35 across I would’ve been stumped today. It all fell into place for me with that revealer. Very clever.
I don't usually comment, but this was such a clever puzzle! It was fun to solve, even though I got the theme fairly early. What a great way to start the day!
Holy moly!!! I loved this!!!!

One of the down columns gave me an idea for an awesome new show: "EMINEM!: VICE COP!"

Every episode ends with the bad guy saying, "I'll beat the rap, Eminem!", who replies, "Oh yeah? Let's see you beat this rap!"

Cue epic rap battle. Roll end credits.

I wonder if our constructor wrote the clue for Eminem-"Nobody wants to see Marshall no more".  Very funny, Marshal!
Very impressive construction and a fun solve, great puzzle!
Seems like more proper nouns than usual.  Typically makes for a more challenging solve.  But fun!
Wow, the effort of just creating a list of so many theme words must have been intense, let alone actually piecing them together into a grid. Hats off to Mr. Hermann!
Tough but rewarding.  Cool theme!
Very nice one! This one was a little tricky for a Tuesday, I thought, but excellent!
Just. Wow!! Fun puzzle.

What a clever puzzle! The vowel-consonant alternation made it a bit tricky, but also made it easy to spot any wrong guesses. Above all, it was *fun*. The genius from Kazakhstan and the name of the band were the icing on the cake.

My hat is off to the constructor. (Bows)
That was a blast! The c/v alternation really made things flow--easy to realize guesses were wrong (except COMET and CUPID).

Kudos! I loved it! 
Made me vibe like music.
Didn't get the "trick" until I had solved the puzzle, and even then it took the constructor's notes to finally get it. But ultimately satisfying and fun.
Inappropriate for a Tuesday. Where is the editorial staff, asleep at the wheel?
Too many of you are being dazzled by the construction to realize this puzzle wasn’t all that fun to solve.
Whoaaaaa --  tough crowd here today!   I thought the consonant vowel back and forth was pretty clever and I liked the puzzle just fine.
Wow, just brilliant.
I loved this one. Yes, there were proper names, but only one was unfamiliar to me and was doable with crosses. I finished in less than avg for a Tues and had fun in the process. Kudos to Mr. Hermann!
As a relatively new crossword solver, i absolutely loved this one! I got vowel very early on and everything started falling into place shortly after.

By far the hardest Tuesday I've ever done. 35A saved me from making some bad mistakes, but didn't help much with correct alternatives. Almost an hour in I was informed I had something wrong, so I looked up ILA B. Wells. I don't know why I had an L there, but I wouldn't have thought of a D either.
Impressive construction and fun to solve—well done!
Fun puzzle! Getting the theme early-ish helped me with quite a few of the other clues.
Took a lot longer than a typical Tuesday, but still it was fun trying to figure it out after I got the pattern.

This is definitely a candidate for POY. 

I had to guess the crossing of AVEDA and IDA. D or R? Don't worry I won't say that word that starts with N.  😂
Wow. Just wow. Apt crossing of 35a and 27d. I think this was one of my favorites, and on a Tuesday?!

This was a great crossword, even better because quite a few people thought it was hard - and I didn't! This doesn't happen often, this may even be the first time.

Even though I didn't know ERIC, IDA. OLETA or MOC, the revealer revealed and made it easier. 

It still took me 40 minutes, but that's usual.
Trickier than the usual Tuesday but well constructed
Wow.  Every other letter.  I can’t even write a sentence that follows this puzzle’s construction.  I’m blown away.
What a brilliant puzzle this was! Hats off 🎩
Very clever and impressive! Grids like this are why I enjoy doing crosswords so much.

I solved this puzzle outdoors, in a scenic, wooded cwm, while my Partner played softly upon his crwth--truly an example of cosmic syzygy!

(IRL, unable to sleep, I solved it at 3:30am in my living room chair; it took me about 1.5x my normal Tues. time--perhaps insomia at play; and my Partner (love him!) is completely unmusical, at least as far as playing or singing.)

Coincidentally, a couple days ago I solved a similar puzzle from the archives: April 9, 2019--also a Tuesday. In that puzzle, all the across entries had clues with the form [x/y]. I'll stop there, lest someone want to back and try it.
Well done. Great theme, fun to solve.
Fun!!
Perec would be happy!

Another late puzzle find. Never seen another one like this. A Friday from February 27, 1976 by Joli Quentin Kasil. Four 15 letter grid- spanning theme answers in that one - three of them placed synchronously as across answers and one more straight down the middle. Those clues and answers: "Ten million squared" IOOOOOOOOOOOOOO "Lots" OODLESANDOODLES "Ten thousand squared" AHUNDREDMILLION "Arabian Nights total" ATHOUSANDANDONE And that last one was the only one to ever appear in another puzzle. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=2/27/1976&g=37&d=A ...
Wow! Super impressive. Hat's off to the constructor. And, noteworthy, no chance for "oreo" or "eel." (But still Eno, though not present)

When I discovered the vowel thing,I realized that some folks are much further and deeper into word and language interplay than I will ever be. Remarkable to have that level of structural command over an entire grid. And with less than 60 clues, which is a sign of a brainy, challenging 15 x 15 puzzle.

What a terrific puzzle, and quite crunchy for a Tuesday. At least it was for me. My usual habit of jumping around the grid a bit while solving stood me in good stead this time, because it meant I discovered the revealer early on. I did have trouble with some of the proper names. I’m the right generation to know about the Plastic ONO Band, but didn’t know the “Soul singer Adams” and a couple of others. I also didn’t see that 55D was “AN I” rather than “ANI”. 
Thanks for a very entertaining puzzle, Marshal Herrmann 😊🥳
This was a very fun puzzle! Took me 10% longer than my average time but felt quick , easy & fun.  Thanks!
I liked it a lot. I was 'avin a time wit it!

I felt this puzzle was very forced but since most crosses were relatively easy it was a quick solve. I have issue with 55D ANI… The use of an indefinite article with another part of the answer. Also, 52D failed to mention it was an abbreviation or that is it known colloquially.

I got mixed up and thought today must be Friday!!

Thanks for the fun puzzle Marshal!
A fairly easy solve, but I'm very impressed by the structure. Bravo!

Oh... one more late puzzle find. Again, something I've never seen before. A Wednesday from February 26,2014 by Ruth B. Margolin. Theme clues and answers: "Journalists covering abstract art?" CUBISTREPORTERS "Help from a jerk?" POMPOUSASSIST "Canned tuna without mayo?" STARKISTNAKED "Narcoleptics with string instruments?" SLEEPERCELLISTS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/26/2014&g=26&d=A ...

This puzzle reminded me of learning about iambic pentameter when I was a sophomore in high school, and hypnotized myself by reading Romeo and Juliet in a steady syllabic rhythm. 

It was fun to admire my finished puzzle with a head-nodding “consonant VOWEL, consonant VOWEL..”
I am insanely impressed with the creation of this puzzle. Alternating both across and down, with four full grid spanners, and not chock full of boring crosswordese. Well done!
This was a challenging Tuesday for me!  How fun!
I didn't notice the theme until I got to the revealer.  Then I said "Holy $#!+" and smiled.  Well done!
This puzzle was fun, good level of difficulty matching the day, and just remarkably created. Really fine moment in my day, to engage with a puzzle this thoughtul.

One thing was sure: OBOE wouldn’t be appearing in today’s puzzle. 

Super impressive and, dare I say, imaginative, construction!
Clever! Loved it
Incredible crossword. Loved the simple elegance of the theme and the long spanners. Rarely am I wowed by a Tuesday but this definitely did it!
wow. impressive constraint solving.
Nicest Monday in a long time. Curious how new solvers find it
Harder than many saturdays.  Who decides which day a puzzle airs, the constructor or the editor?
Wow! That's impressive!
This was so fun, super clever, and got a :O (!) out of me when I got to the revealed. I love when the construction is the “theme”
Really standout of a puzzle. Had me wondering if some custom code had to be written just for the constraint.
One of my favourite crosswords until now
Strong contender for puzzle of the year. So subtle and so impressive.
@Dan It still has me buffaloed. Your insight would be appreciated.
@fehstik In the commercial world, one of the most popular phones is the iPhone. Put an I in front of PHONE and you’ve got an Apple brand name.

@Dan

Yeah, that one confused me at first too.

@fehstik 
It took me a while, but I solve on an Android, not ANI phone (AN I-phone).

@Dan

It fits in with the "Wheel of Fortune" motif:
As in, "I'd like to buy AN I."

Does this count as a DOOK?

@Beth in Greenbelt Actually it would be impossible to construct a crossword with alternating vowels and consonants in every word without also doing what you noticed (i.e. the empty squares "maintaining the pattern"). You can use what's called "a parity argument" for this, but just to illustrate: let's say you have something like this:
1x2
345
Here 1 is the last letter of one word, x is a black square, 2 is the first letter of the next word, 345 are the three letters under 1x2. If 1 is a vowel, then 3 must be a consonant, so 4 must be a vowel, so 5 must be a consonant, so 2 must be a vowel.
(To be precise, you can't avoid this unless the crossword is broken off into several disconnected parts by the black squares, but that is against crossword construction "rules".)

@Andrzej
The naming of cars - I believe Rolls Royce was going to name one of their models Silver Mist, until it was pointed out that Mist is the German word for 'manure'. So they say.

We don't have a naming difference between cars related to doors. We used to use 'hatchback' but this seems to have lapsed. Extra-long cars were 'estate cars' but they seem to have gone too.

There are 3-door and 5-door (the boot counts as a door) cars and you occasionally see extra, extra long novelty cars called 'limos' that people hire for parties. Bloated cars are now referred to as SUVs, very common in wealthy areas for the school run, but not for sport or 'utility'.

As far as I know, they are all usually referred to as cars.

@Eric Hougland
As I remember it, two of the kingdoms in BOTR were Tudor and Fordor.

@Joe

Would that have been FOTR...Ford of the Rings?

@Jane Wheelaghan

We had hatchbacks at one time here, but now, anything that has a hatch is called an SUV (Sport Utility Vehicle).  Occasionally, you'll hear a compact one called a CUV, but I think that's mostly marketing speak.

What you called "estate cars" we called "station wagons"--big enough for a hotel to collect people at the train station, I guess.  Minivans and then large SUVs replaced them when people realized these were more comfortable, with more headroom, legroom and cargo room.

Boots are trunks here, and bonnets are hoods.

Most Americans consider SUVs cars, but technically they're classified as trucks because of their body design, which is similar to trucks.  And of course, trucks are lorries.  And here, Lorrie is just a girl's name.

@Ken

I agree. The “modern construction tools” make it possible for almost anyone to construct a crossword puzzle, but it can be a lot of work to construct a *good* puzzle.

 What impressed me about this one was that despite the limitations imposed by the vowel/consonant pattern, the fill is overall pretty good. 

It’s easy to complain about one or two icky bits of fill. But unless you try to rework the puzzle to eliminate those yucky bits, you can’t know if they’re the only words that hold the grid together.
And today's wet blanket award goes to...
@Jeb Jones he also said he worked on on it for over a year

I figured there was be pushback, but as far as the solving went, I thought the fill and the cluing were average. Not bad, but not all that interesting. And therefore not really worth giving up a theme for.

While I maintain that the construction was neither clever nor difficult, I can see it taking a long time. Some (maybe many) grid patterns would likely be unfillable given the remaining word list. Others would surely  produce results with too much undesirable fill. It probably took a good deal of tweaking to get something publishable, but what it was missing was art (IMO of course, YMMV).

I have written programs to do this kind of thing before. There is a huge space of options to try and there will also be MANY potential fills, so you can’t do an exhaustive search. What you can do is weight all of the words and phrases on your list for goodness (probably already done), choose a grid pattern (where to put the black squares), put in the fill you want (revealer, spanners, whatever) and then use a greedy algorithm to depth-first fill the grid, trying to maximize some goodness value. Whenever it spits out a result, see how it looks/feels. If you aren’t getting good results from a particular grid pattern (and most probably won’t be), tweak it a bit and try again, and again. When you get close to something good, you can tweak more selectively.

@Linda Jo If you've never heard of Ida B.Wells, you owe it to yourself, your understanding of the history of the suffragette movement and the civil rights movement, and above all to the need to honor this incredible woman, to read the Wikipedia entry about her: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ida_B._Wells And now, a little mini-essay about puzzle criticism. I will now put on my pedantic nitpicker's hat and make an observation, as follows: "Ahem." (leans forward, arches one eyebrow) "When a vehicle is 'totalled,' it does NOT mean that it is damaged beyond repair. It simply means that the cost of said repair would exceed the 'blue book' figure for the cost of a similar vehicle, in which case the insurance company provides the owner with a check for said amount and takes possession of the vehicle as salvage. Once this happens, said vehicle may very well eventually end up in the hands of someone with some mechanical expertise who will, using his or her own skills and time, put it in working order and either sell it or use it as their own vehicle." I now remove the hat, slouch a bit, and note that "totalled" in popular usage is usually taken to mean "damaged beyond repair," so it's close enough for crosswords. No error, no penalty. Plus you have to leave constructors a little wiggle room on the clueing...if someone magically pulls a rabbit out of a thimble, the music plays, and the crowd roars, you're not justified in winging about the quality of the bunny. Got it?
